importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan's successful launch of its first hyperspectral satellite, highlighting a significant advancement in national space capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame from August to December 2025 reflects the period during which Pakistan's space programme has seen rapid development, including the launch and potential full operationalization of the H1 satellite and other orbital satellites.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a major milestone in its space programme.
The H1 satellite was launched from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, by Pakistan’s space agency SUPARCO.
Hyperspectral imaging enables detection of subtle material or chemical changes on Earth's surface, useful for crop quality monitoring, water resource tracking, and disaster damage assessment.
The satellite supports national priorities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management.
The technology is expected to enhance Pakistan’s ability to identify geohazard risks, contributing to development projects like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
This launch is a key step in strengthening Pakistan’s space capabilities and reflects its strategic partnership with China in peaceful space exploration.
Pakistan has launched three satellites into orbit this year: H1, EO-1, and KS-1, with EO-1 and KS-1 already fully operational.
It may take about two months to calibrate the H1 satellite’s systems before it becomes fully operational in 2025.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in South Asia, the subject of the satellite launch and the nation benefiting from the technological advancement.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan’s launch of its first hyperspectral satellite signifies a strategic advancement in national science, technology, and development planning, especially in agriculture and disaster preparedness.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s national space agency responsible for the launch and management of the H1 satellite.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is directly involved in the execution and announcement of the satellite mission, representing Pakistan’s institutional commitment to space technology development.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s first hyperspectral satellite launched into orbit on October 19, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite is central to the article, as it enables advanced Earth observation capabilities for agriculture, environmental monitoring, and disaster management.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A space launch facility located in northwestern China, where the H1 satellite was launched.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It highlights Pakistan's international collaboration with China, using China's launch infrastructure to achieve its space goals.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nation with which Pakistan has a strategic partnership, especially in space technology and the CPEC infrastructure project.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China is a key partner in Pakistan’s space programme, providing launch services and reflecting broader geopolitical cooperation between the two nations.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure initiative linking China’s Xinjiang province to Pakistan’s Gwadar Port.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite’s geohazard monitoring capabilities are expected to support the safety and sustainability of CPEC infrastructure development.

namedEntities.name: EO-1 and KS-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Two other satellites launched by Pakistan this year, which are already fully operational in orbit.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They provide context for Pakistan’s growing space programme and demonstrate progress beyond the H1 launch, showing a broader trend of national space capability development.

namedEntities.name: Precision agriculture
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A farming method using technology to optimize crop yields and resource use.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite will directly support precision agriculture by enabling better crop quality and soil condition monitoring.

namedEntities.name: Environmental monitoring
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The ongoing tracking of environmental conditions such as air and water quality.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The hyperspectral data allows for detailed environmental monitoring, improving Pakistan’s ability to manage natural resources sustainably.

namedEntities.name: Disaster management
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The process of preparing for, responding to, and recovering from natural disasters.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite enhances Pakistan’s capacity to detect and respond to disaster-related damage, improving national resilience.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, marking a significant milestone in its space programme. The satellite, developed by the national space agency SUPARCO, is designed to detect subtle material changes on Earth’s surface, enabling advanced monitoring of crop quality, water resources, and disaster damage. This technological advancement supports national priorities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management. The mission strengthens Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China and contributes to development initiatives such as the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), by improving geohazard risk detection. While the H1 satellite is expected to be fully operational within two months, Pakistan’s space programme has already seen progress with the full operational status of two earlier satellites, EO-1 and KS-1, launched this year.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
